article.paragraph: Down syndrome(DSorDNS) orDown's syndrome, also known astrisomy 21, is agenetic disordercaused by the presence of all or part of a third copy ofchromosome 21 (human)chromosome 21.cite journalPattersonDMolecular genetic analysis of Down syndrome.Human GeneticsJul 20091261195–2141952625110.1007/s00439-009-0696-8It is typically associated withchild developmentphysical growthdelays, characteristicdysmorphic featurefacial features, and mild to moderateintellectual disability.cite journalWeijermanMEde Winter, JPClinical practice. The care of children with Down syndrome.European journal of pediatricsDec 2010169121445–522063218710.1007/s00431-010-1253-0The averageIQof a young adult with Down syndrome is 50, equivalent to the mental age of an 8- or 9-year-old child, but this varies widely.

Down syndrome can be identified during pregnancy byprenatal screeningfollowed by diagnostic testing, or after birth by direct observation and genetic testing. Since the introduction of screening, pregnancies with the diagnosis are oftenabortionterminated.RegularScreening_(medicine)screeningfor health problems common in Down syndrome is recommended throughout the person's life.

Education and proper care have been shown to improvequality of life.cite journalRoizen, NJ; Patterson, DDown's syndromeLancet36193651281–89April 20031269996710.1016/S0140-6736(03)12987-XReviewSome children with Down syndrome are educated in typical school classes, while others require more specialized education.Some individuals with Down syndrome graduate from high school and a few attendpost-secondary education.In adulthood, about 20% in the United States do paid work in some capacitywith many requiring a sheltered work environment.cite webFacts About Down SyndromeNational Association for Down Syndromehttp://www.nads.org/pages_new/facts.html20 March 2012Support in financial and legal matters is often needed.Life expectancy is around 50 to 60 years in the developed world with proper health care.

preblock.preline: Down syndrome is one of the most commonchromosome abnormalitychromosome abnormalitiesin humans,occurring in about one per 1000 babies born each year.In 2013 it resulted in 36,000 deaths down from 43,000 deaths in 1990.cite journalGBD 2013 Mortality and Causes of DeathCollaboratorsGlobal, regional, and national age-sex specific all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 240 causes of death, 1990-2013: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2013.Lancet17 December 20142553044210.1016/S0140-6736(14)61682-2It is named afterJohn Langdon Down, the British doctor who fully described the syndrome in 1866.Some aspects of the condition were described earlier byJean-tienne Dominique Esquirolin 1838 anddouard Sguinin 1844.cite bookEvans-MartinF. FayDown syndrome2009Chelsea HouseNew York978-1-4381-1950-212http://books.google.ca/books?idThe genetic cause of Down syndromean extra copy of chromosome 21was identified by French researchers in 1959.

article.heading: Physical
article.paragraph: File:Feet of a boy with Down Syndrome.JPGthumbupright=1.4Feet of a boy with Down syndromePeople with Down syndrome may have some or all of these physical characteristics: amicrogeniasmall chin, slanted eyes,Hypotoniapoor muscle tone, a flatnasal bridge, aSingle transverse palmar creasesingle crease of the palm, and a protruding tongue due to a small mouth and relativelymacroglossialarge tongue.These airway changes lead toobstructive sleep apneain around half of those with Down syndrome.Other common features include: a flat and wide face,a short neck, excessive joint flexibility, extra space betweenHalluxbig toeand second toe, abnormalDermatoglyphicspatterns on the fingertipsand short fingers.Instability of theatlantoaxial jointoccurs in about 20% and may lead tospinal cord injuryin 12%.Hip dislocationsmay occur without trauma in up to a third of people with Down syndrome.

Growth in height is slower, resulting in adults who tend to haveshort staturethe average height for men is 154 cm (5 ft 1 in) and for women is 142 cm (4 ft 8 in).cite bookWilliams Textbook of Endocrinology Expert Consult2011Elsevier Health SciencesLondon978-1-4377-3600-7http://books.google.ca/books?id12thIndividuals with Down syndrome are at increased risk for obesity as they age.Growth chartshave been developed specifically for children with Down syndrome.
article.heading: Neurological
article.paragraph: Most individuals with Down syndrome have mild (IQ: 5070) or moderate (IQ: 3550)intellectual disabilitywith some cases having severe (IQ: 2035) difficulties.cite journalReillyCBehavioural phenotypes and special educational needs: is aetiology important in the classroom?Journal of intellectual disability research : JIDROct 20125610929–462247135610.1111/j.1365-2788.2012.01542.xThose withMosaic (genetics)mosaicDown syndrome typically have IQ scores 1030 points higher.cite bookChildren with disabilities2005Paul H. BrookesBaltimore [u.a.]978-1-55766-581-2308http://books.google.ca/books?id5thBatshaw, MarkAs they age, people with Down syndrome typically perform less well compared to their same-age peers.cite journalPattersonTRapsey, CMGlue, PSystematic review of cognitive development across childhood in Down syndrome: implications for treatment interventions.Journal of intellectual disability research : JIDRApr 2013574306–182350614110.1111/j.1365-2788.2012.01536.xSome after 30 years of age may lose their ability to speak.This syndrome causes about a third of cases of intellectual disability.Many developmental milestones are delayed with the ability to crawl typically occurring around 8 months rather than 5 months and the ability to walk independently typically occurring around 21 months rather than 14 months.cite bookRondaledited by Jean-AdolpheTherapies and rehabilitation in Down syndrome2007J. Wiley & SonsChichester, England978-0-470-31997-0116http://books.google.ca/books?idQuartino, Alberto Rasore

Commonly, individuals with Down syndrome have better language understanding than ability to speak.Between 10 and 45% have either astutterorclutteringrapid and irregular speech, making it difficult to understand them.cite journalKentRDVorperian, HKSpeech impairment in Down syndrome: a review.Journal of speech, language, and hearing research : JSLHRFeb 2013561178–2102327539710.1044/1092-4388(2012/12-0148)They typically do fairly well with social skills.Behavior problems are not generally as great an issue as in other syndromes associated with intellectual disability.In children with Down syndrome,mental illnessoccurs in nearly 30% withautism spectrumautismoccurring in 510%.People with Down syndrome experience a wide range of emotions.cite bookMcGuireDennis and Chicoine, BrianMental Wellness in Adults with Down Syndrome2006Woodbine House, Inc.Bethesday, MD1-890627-65-849While generally happy,cite bookMarguliesPhillipDown syndrome2007Rosen Pub. GroupNew York978-1-4042-0695-35http://books.google.ca/books?id1stsymptoms ofDepression (mood)depressionandanxietymay develop in early adulthood.

Children and adults with Down syndrome are at increased risk ofepileptic seizureswhich occur in 510% of children and up to 50% of adults.This includes an increased risk of a specific type of seizure calledinfantile spasms.Many (15%) who live 40 years or longer developAlzheimer disease.cite bookThe 5-minute pediatric consult2012Wolters Kluwer Health/Lippincott Williams & WilkinsPhiladelphia978-1-4511-1656-4289http://books.google.ca/books?id6thM. William SchwartzIn those who reach 60 years of age, 5070% have the disease.
article.heading: Senses
article.paragraph: File:Brushfield eye crop.jpgthumbupright=1.5Brushfield spots, visible in the irises of a baby with Down syndromeHearing and vision disorders occur in more than half of people with Down syndrome.cite journalHickeyFHickey, ESummar, KLMedical update for children with Down syndrome for the pediatrician and family practitioner.Advances in pediatrics2012591137–572278957710.1016/j.yapd.2012.04.006

preblock.preline: Vision problems occur in 38 to 80%.Between 20 and 50% havestrabismus, in which the two eyes do not move together.Cataracts(cloudiness of the lens of the eye) occur in 15%,and may be present at birth.Keratoconus(a thin, cone-shaped cornea)andglaucoma(increased eye pressure) are also more common,as arerefractive errorsrequiring glasses or contacts.Brushfield spots(small white or grayish/brown spots on the outer part of theiris (anatomy)iris) are present in 38 to 85% of individuals.

Hearing problems are found in 5090% of children with Down syndrome.This is often the result ofotitis media with effusionwhich occurs in 5070%and chronicotitis mediaear infectionswhich occur in 40 to 60%.cite bookEvans-MartinF. FayDown syndrome2009Chelsea HouseNew York978-1-4381-1950-271http://books.google.ca/books?idEar infections often begin in the first year of life and are partly due to pooreustachian tubefunction.cite bookHandbook of neurodevelopmental and genetic disorders in children2011Guilford PressNew York978-1-60623-990-2365http://books.google.ca/books?id2ndSam GoldsteinExcessive ear wax can also cause hearing loss due to obstruction of the outer ear canal.Even a mild degree of hearing loss can have negative consequences for speech, language understanding, and academics.Additionally, it is important to rule out hearing loss as a factor in social and cognitive deterioration.cite bookeditorVee P. Prasher,Neuropsychological assessments of dementia in Down syndrome and intellectual disabilities2009SpringerLondon978-1-84800-249-456http://books.google.ca/books?idAge-related hearing loss of theSensorineural hearing losssensorineural typeoccurs at a much earlier age and affects 1070% of people with Down syndrome.

article.heading: Heart
article.paragraph: The rate ofcongenital heart diseasein newborns with Down syndrome is around 40%.Of those with heart disease, about 80% have anatrioventricular septal defectorventricular septal defectwith the first being more common.Mitral valveproblems become common as people age, even in those without heart problems at birth.Other problems that may occur includetetralogy of Fallotandpatent ductus arteriosus.cite bookTintinalli, Judith E.Emergency Medicine: A Comprehensive Study Guide (Emergency Medicine (Tintinalli))McGraw-Hill CompaniesNew York2010Chapter 138The Child with Special Health Care Needs0-07-148480-9People with Down syndrome have a lower risk ofatherosclerosishardening of the arteries.
article.heading: Cancer
article.paragraph: Although the overall risk of cancer is not changed,cite bookRichard UrbanoHealth Issues Among Persons With Down Syndromehttp://books.google.com/books?id9 September 2010Academic Press978-0-12-374477-7129the risk of leukemia andtesticular canceris increased and risk of solid cancers is reduced.Solid cancers are believed to be less common due to increased expression oftumor suppressor genespresent on chromosome 21.cite bookCancer genome and tumor microenvironment2010SpringerNew York978-1-4419-0711-0203http://books.google.ca/books?idOnline-Ausg.Andrei Thomas-Tikhonenko

LeukemiaCancers of the bloodare 10 to 15 times more common in children with Down syndrome.In particular,acute lymphoblastic leukemiais 20 times more common and themegakaryoblasticform ofacute myelogenous leukemiais 500 times more common.Transientmyeloproliferative disease, a disorder of blood cell production that does not occur outside of Down syndrome, affects 310% of infants.cite journalSeewaldLTaub, JWMaloney, KWMcCabe, ERAcute leukemias in children with Down syndrome.Molecular genetics and metabolismSep 20121071–225–302286788510.1016/j.ymgme.2012.07.011cite journalGamisASSmith, FOTransient myeloproliferative disorder in children with Down syndrome: clarity to this enigmatic disorder.British journal of haematologyNov 20121593277–872296682310.1111/bjh.12041The disorder is typically not serious but occasionally can be.It resolves most times without treatment; however, in those who have had it, a 20 to 30% risk of developing acute lymphoblastic leukemia at a later time exists.
article.heading: Endocrine
article.paragraph: Problems of thethyroid glandoccur in 2050% of individuals with Down syndrome.HypothyroidismLow thyroidis the most common form, occurring in almost half of all individuals.Thyroid problems can be due to a poorly or nonfunctioning thyroid at birth (known ascongenital hypothyroidism) which occurs in 1%or can develop later due to an attack on the thyroid by theimmune systemresulting inGraves diseaseorautoimmune hypothyroidism.cite journalGraberEChacko, ERegelmann, MOCostin, GRapaport, RDown syndrome and thyroid function.Endocrinology and metabolism clinics of North AmericaDec 2012414735–452309926710.1016/j.ecl.2012.08.008Type 1 diabetes mellitusis also more common.
article.heading: Gastrointestinal
article.paragraph: Constipation occurs in nearly half of people with Down syndrome and may result in changes in behavior.One potential cause isHirschsprung's disease, occurring in 215%, which is due to a lack of nerve cells controlling thecolon (anatomy)colon.cite journalMooreSWDown syndrome and the enteric nervous system.Pediatric surgery internationalAug 2008248873–831863362310.1007/s00383-008-2188-7Other frequent congenital problems includeduodenal atresia,pyloric stenosis,Meckel diverticulum, andimperforate anus.Celiac diseaseaffects about 720%andgastroesophageal reflux diseaseis also more common.
article.heading: Fertility
article.paragraph: Males with Down syndrome usually do not father children, while females have lower rates of fertility relative to those who are unaffected.Fertility is estimated to be present in 3050% of females.Menopausetypically occurs at an earlier age.The poor fertility in males is thought to be due to problems withspermatogenesissperm development; however, it may also be related to not being sexually active.As of 2006, three instances of males with Down syndrome fathering children and 26 cases of females having children have been reported.cite journalPradhan, M; Dalal, A; Khan, F; Agrawal, SFertility in men with Down syndrome: a case reportFertil Steril8661765.e1–320061709498810.1016/j.fertnstert.2006.03.071Withoutpreimplantation genetic diagnosisassisted reproductive technologies, around half of the children of someone with Down syndrome will also have the syndrome.
article.heading: Genetics
article.paragraph: MainGenetics of Down syndromeDown syndrome is caused by having three copies of thegenesonchromosome 21, rather than the usual two.cite journalLana-ElolaEWatson-Scales, SDFisher, EMTybulewicz, VLDown syndrome: searching for the genetic culprits.Disease models & mechanismsSep 201145586–952187845910.1242/dmm.0080783180222The parents of the affected individual are typically genetically normal.cite bookHammeredited by Stephen J. McPhee, Gary D.Pathophysiology of disease : an introduction to clinical medicine2010McGraw-Hill MedicalNew York978-0-07-162167-0Chapter 26thPathophysiology of Selected Genetic DiseasesThose who have one child with Down syndrome have about a 1% risk of having a second child with the syndrome, if both parents are found to have normal karyotypes.

The extra chromosome content can arise through several different ways. The most common cause (about 9295% of cases) is a complete extra copy of chromosome 21, resulting intrisomy21.cite webhttp://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/birthdefects/DownSyndrome.htmlCDC—Birth Defects, Down Syndrome—NCBDDDCdc.gov2013-11-06In 1.0 to 2.5% of cases, some of the cells in the body are normal and others have trisomy 21, known asmosaic (genetics)mosaicDown syndrome.cite bookTreatment & prognosis in pediatrics.2013Jaypee Brothers Medical P978-93-5090-428-2391http://books.google.ca/books?idKausik MandalThe other common mechanisms that can give rise to Down syndrome include: aRobertsonian translocation,isochromosome, orring chromosome. These contain additional material from chromosome 21 and occur in about 2.5% of cases.An isochromosome results when the two long arms of a chromosome separate together rather than the long and short arm separating together duringmeiosisegg or sperm development.cite bookEssentials of Rubin's Pathology2013Lippincott Williams & Wilkins978-1-4511-8132-6129–131http://books.google.ca/books?idHoward Reisner
article.heading: Trisomy 21
article.paragraph: File:Down Syndrome Karyotype.pngthumbupright=1.4Karyotypefor trisomy Down syndrome: Notice the three copies of chromosome 21Trisomy 21 (also known by thekaryotype47,XX,+21 for females and 47,XY,+21 for males)cite bookFletcher-Janzenedited by Cecil R. Reynolds, ElaineEncyclopedia of special education a reference for the education of children, adolescents, and adults with disabilities and other exceptional individuals2007John Wiley & SonsNew York978-0-470-17419-7458http://books.google.ca/books?id3rdis caused by a failure of the 21st chromosome to separate during egg or sperm development.As a result, a sperm or egg cell is produced with an extra copy of chromosome 21; this cell thus has 24 chromosomes. When combined with a normal cell from the other parent, the baby has 47 chromosomes, with three copies of chromosome 21.About 88% of cases of trisomy 21 result from nonseparation of the chromosomes in the mother, 8% from nonseparation in the father, and 3% after the egg and sperm have merged.cite bookZhangedited by Liang Cheng, David Y.Molecular genetic pathology2008HumanaTotowa, N.J.978-1-59745-405-645http://books.google.ca/books?id
article.heading: Translocation
article.paragraph: The extra chromosome 21 material may also occur due to aRobertsonian translocationin 24% cases.In this situation, the long arm of chromosome 21 is attached to another chromosome, oftenChromosome 14 (human)chromosome 14.In a male affected with Down syndrome, it results in a karyotype of 46XY,t(14q21q).cite bookHuman Heredity: Principles and Issues2013Cengage Learning978-1-285-52847-2138http://books.google.ca/books?idMichael Cummings10cite bookYen and Jaffe's reproductive endocrinology : physiology, pathophysiology, and clinical management2009Saunders/ElsevierPhiladelphia, PA978-1-4160-4907-4791http://books.google.ca/books?idJerome Frank Strauss, Robert L. Barbieri6thThis may be a new mutation or previously present in one of the parents.The parent with such a translocation is usually normal physically and mentally;however, during production of egg or sperm cells, a higher chance of creating reproductive cells with extra chromosome 21 material exists.cite bookFamily Medicine Principles and Practice2013Springer New YorkNew York, NY978-0-387-21744-4142http://books.google.ca/books?idA.K. DavidSixthThis results in a 15% chance of having a child with Down syndrome when the mother is affected and a less than 5% probability if the father is affected.The probability of this type of Down syndrome is not related to the mother's age.Some children without Down syndrome may inherit the translocation and have a higher probability of having children of their own with Down syndrome.In this case it is sometimes known as familial Down syndrome.cite bookShafferR.J. McKinlay Gardner, Grant R. Sutherland, Lisa G.Chromosome abnormalities and genetic counseling2012Oxford University PressOxford978-0-19-974915-7292http://books.google.ca/books?id4th
article.heading: Mechanism
article.paragraph: The extra genetic material present in DS results in overexpression of a portion of the 310 genes located on chromosome 21.This overexpression has been estimated at around 50%.Some research has suggested the Down syndrome critical region is located at bands 21q22.1q22.3,cite webhttp://emedicine.medscape.com/article/943216-overviewGenetics of Down syndrome2011-05-29with this area including genes for amyloid,superoxide dismutase, and likely theETS-2 proto oncogene.cite bookCurrent diagnosis & treatment psychiatry2008McGraw-Hill MedicalNew York0-07-142292-7Chapter 32ndMichael H. EbertPsychiatric GeneticsOther research, however, has not confirmed these findings.

The dementia which occurs in Down syndrome is due to an excess ofamyloid beta peptideproduced in the brain and is similar toAlzheimer's disease.This peptide is processed fromamyloid precursor protein, the gene for which is located on chromosome 21.cite journalWekslerMESzabo, PRelkin, NRReidenberg, MMWeksler, BBCoppus, AMAlzheimer's disease and Down's syndrome: treating two paths to dementia.Autoimmunity reviewsApr 2013126670–32320192010.1016/j.autrev.2012.10.013Senile plaquesandneurofibrillary tanglesare present in nearly all by 35 years of age, though dementia may not be present.Those with DS also lack a normal number oflymphocytesand produce lessantibodyantibodieswhich contributes to their increased risk of infection.
article.heading: Epigenetics
article.paragraph: Down syndrome is associated with an increased risk of many chronic diseases that are typically associated with older age such as Alzheimer's disease. The accelerated aging suggest that trisomy 21 increases the biological age of tissues, but molecular evidence for this hypothesis is sparse. According to a biomarker of tissue age known asBiological clock (aging)epigenetic clock, trisomy 21 increases the age of blood and brain tissue (on average by 6.6 years).Cite journalAccelerated epigenetic aging in Down syndrome.[[Aging Cell]]1432015http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/acel.12325/epdf25678027Horvath S, Garagnani P, Bacalini MG, Pirazzini C, Salvioli S, Gentilini D, Di Blasio AM, Giuliani C, Tung S, Vinters HV, Franceschi C
article.heading: Screening
article.paragraph: Guidelines recommend screening for Down syndrome to be offered to all pregnant women, regardless of age.cite webCG62: Antenatal carehttp://publications.nice.org.uk/antenatal-care-cg62London: National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence16 February 2013National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence2008A number of tests are used, with varying levels of accuracy. They are typically used in combination to increase the detection rate.None can be definitive, thus if screening is positive, eitheramniocentesisorchorionic villous samplingis required to confirm the diagnosis.Screening in both the first and second trimesters is better than just screening in the first trimester.The different screening techniques in use are able to pick up 90 to 95% of cases with a false-positive rate of 2 to 5%.

article.heading: Ultrasound
article.paragraph: File:T21.JPGthumbupright=1.4Ultrasound of fetus with Down syndrome showing amegacystislarge bladderFile:Nuchal edema in Down Syndrome Dr. W. Moroder.jpgthumbupright=1.4Enlarged NT and absent nasal bone in a fetus at 11 weeks with Down syndromeUltrasound imaging can be used to screen for Down syndrome. Findings that indicate increased risk when seen at 14 to 24 weeks ofgestationinclude a small or no nasal bone,ventriculomegalylarge ventricles,nuchal fold thickness, and an abnormal rightsubclavian artery, among others.cite journalAgathokleousMChaveeva, PPoon, LCKosinski, PNicolaides, KHMeta-analysis of second-trimester markers for trisomy 21.Ultrasound in obstetrics & gynecology : the official journal of the International Society of Ultrasound in Obstetrics and GynecologyMar 2013413247–612320874810.1002/uog.12364The presence or absence of many markers is more accurate.Increased fetalnuchal translucency(NT) indicates an increased risk of Down syndrome picking up 7580% of cases and being falsely positive in 6%.cite journalMaloneFDD'Alton, ME; Society for Maternal-Fetal, MedicineFirst-trimester sonographic screening for Down syndrome.Obstetrics and gynecologyNov 20031025 Pt 11066–791467248910.1016/j.obstetgynecol.2003.08.004
article.heading: Blood tests
article.paragraph: Several blood markers can be measured to predict the risk of Down syndrome during the first or second trimester.Testing in both trimesters is sometimes recommended and test results are often combined with ultrasound results.In the second trimester, often two or three tests are used in combination with two or three of:-fetoprotein, unconjugated estriol, total hCG, and free hCG detecting about 6070% of cases.cite journalAlldredSKDeeks, JJGuo, BNeilson, JPAlfirevic, ZSecond trimester serum tests for Down's Syndrome screening.The Cochrane database of systematic reviewsJun 13, 20126CD0099252269638810.1002/14651858.CD009925

Testing of the mother's blood for fetal DNA is being studied and appears promising in the first trimester.cite journalVerweijEJvan den Oever, JM; de Boer, MA; Boon, EM; Oepkes, DDiagnostic accuracy of noninvasive detection of fetal trisomy 21 in maternal blood: a systematic review.Fetal diagnosis and therapy201231281–62209492310.1159/000333060The International Society for Prenatal Diagnosis considers it a reasonable screening option for those women whose pregnancies are at a high risk for trisomy 21.Accuracy has been reported at 98.6% in the first trimester of pregnancy.Confirmatory testing by invasive techniques (amniocentesis, CVS) is still required to confirm the screening result.cite journalBennPBorrell, ACuckle, HDugoff, LGross, SJohnson, JAMaymon, ROdibo, ASchielen, PSpencer, KWright, DYaron, YPrenatal Detection of Down Syndrome using Massively Parallel Sequencing (MPS): a rapid response statement from a committee on behalf of the Board of the International Society for Prenatal Diagnosis, 24 October 2011.Prenatal diagnosisJan 20123211–222275335http://www.ispdhome.org/public/news/2011/ISPD_RapidResponse_MPS_24Oct11.pdf10.1002/pd.2919
article.heading: Diagnosis
Before birth
article.paragraph: When screening tests predict a high risk of Down syndrome, a more invasive diagnostic test (amniocentesisorchorionic villus sampling) is needed to confirm the diagnosis.If Down syndrome occurs in one in 500 pregnancies and the test used has a 5% false-positive rate, this means, of 28 women who test positive on screening, only one will have Down syndrome confirmed.cite journalCanickJPrenatal screening for trisomy 21: recent advances and guidelines.Clinical chemistry and laboratory medicine : CCLM / FESCCJun 20125061003–82179050510.1515/cclm.2011.671If the screening test has a 2% false-positive rate, this means one of 10 who test positive on screening have a fetus with DS.Amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling are more reliable tests, but they increase the risk ofmiscarriagebetween 0.5 and 1%.cite journalTaborAAlfirevic, ZUpdate on procedure-related risks for prenatal diagnosis techniques.Fetal diagnosis and therapy20102711–72005166210.1159/000271995The risk of limb problems is increased in the offspring due to the procedure.The risk from the procedure is greater the earlier it is performed, thus amniocentesis is not recommended before 15 weeks gestational age and chorionic villus sampling before 10 weeks gestational age.
article.heading: Abortion rates
article.paragraph: About 92% of pregnancies in Europe with a diagnosis of Down syndrome are terminated.cite journalMansfieldCHopfer, SMarteau, TMTermination rates after prenatal diagnosis of Down syndrome, spina bifida, anencephaly, and Turner and Klinefelter syndromes: a systematic literature review. European Concerted Action: DADA (Decision-making After the Diagnosis of a fetal Abnormality).Prenatal diagnosisSep 1999199808–121052183610.1002/(sici)1097-0223(199909)19:9<808::aid-pd637>3.0.co;2-bIn the United States, termination rates are around 67%, but this varies significantly depending upon the population evaluated.cite journalNatoliJLAckerman, DLMcDermott, SEdwards, JGPrenatal diagnosis of Down syndrome: a systematic review of termination rates (1995–2011).Prenatal diagnosisFeb 2012322142–532241895810.1002/pd.2910When nonpregnant people are asked if they would have a termination if their fetus tested positive, 2333% said yes, when high-risk pregnant women were asked, 4686% said yes, and when women who screened positive are asked, 8997% say yes.cite journalChoiHVan Riper, MThoyre, SDecision making following a prenatal diagnosis of Down syndrome: an integrative review.Journal of midwifery & women's healthMar–Apr 2012572156–642243248810.1111/j.1542-2011.2011.00109.x
article.heading: After birth
article.paragraph: The diagnosis can often be suspected based on the child's physical appearance at birth.An analysis of the child's chromosomes is needed to confirm the diagnosis, and to determine if aChromosomal translocationtranslocationis present, as this may help determine the risk of the child's parents having further children with Down syndrome.Parents generally wish to know the possible diagnosis once it is suspected and do not wish pity.
article.heading: Management
article.paragraph: Efforts such asearly childhood intervention, screening for common problems, medical treatment where indicated, a good family environment, and work-related training can improve the development of children with Down syndrome. Education and proper care can improvequality of life.Raising a child with Down syndrome is more work for parents than raising an unaffected child.cite journalSheets KB, Crissman BG, Feist CD, etalPractice guidelines for communicating a prenatal or postnatal diagnosis of Down syndrome: recommendations of the national society of genetic counselorsJ Genet Couns205432–41October 20112161806010.1007/s10897-011-9375-8Typical childhoodvaccinationsare recommended.

article.paragraph: A number of health organizations have issued recommendations forscreening (medicine)screeningthose with Down syndrome for particular diseases.This is recommended to be done systematically.

At birth, all children should get anelectrocardiogramandechocardiogramultrasound of the heart.Surgical repair of heart problems may be required as early as three months of age.Heart valveproblems may occur in young adults, and further ultrasound evaluation may be needed in adolescents and in early adulthood.Due to the elevated risk of testicular cancer, some recommend checking the person's testicles yearly.
article.heading: Cognitive development

preblock.preline: Hearing aidsor other amplification devices can be useful for language learning in those with hearing loss.Speech-Language PathologySpeech therapymay be useful and is recommended to be started around 9 months of age.As those with Down's typically have good hand-eye coordination, learningsign languagemay be possible.Augmentative and alternative communicationmethods, such as pointing, body language, objects, or pictures, are often used to help with communication.cite journalMent Retard Dev Disabil Res Rev200713126–35Language and communication development in Down syndromeRoberts, JE; Price, J; Malkin, C10.1002/mrdd.2013617326116Behavioral issues and mental illness are typically managed with counseling or medications.

Education programs before reaching school age may be useful.School-age children with Down syndrome may benefit frominclusive education(whereby students of differing abilities are placed in classes with their peers of the same age), provided some adjustments are made to the curriculum.cite webInclusion: Educating Students with Down Syndrome with Their Non-Disabled Peershttp://www.kcdsg.org/files/content/Educating%20Students%20with%20Down%20Syndrome%20With%20Their%20Typical%20Peers.pdfNational Down Syndrome Society5 February 2014Evidence to support this, however, is not very strong.cite journalLindsayGEducational psychology and the effectiveness of inclusive education/mainstreaming.The British journal of educational psychologyMar 200777Pt 11–241741148510.1348/000709906x156881In the United States, theIndividuals with Disabilities Education Actof 1975 requires public schools generally to allow attendance by students with Down's.cite bookNewRebecca S.Early childhood education an international encyclopedia2007Praeger PublishersWestport, Conn.978-0-313-01448-2305http://books.google.ca/books?idCochran, Moncrieff

article.heading: Other
article.paragraph: Tympanostomy tubesare often neededand often more than one set during the person's childhood.cite journalRodmanRPine, HSThe otolaryngologist's approach to the patient with Down syndrome.Otolaryngologic clinics of North AmericaJun 2012453599–629, vii–viii2258803910.1016/j.otc.2012.03.010Tonsillectomyis also often done to help with sleep apnea andpharyngitisthroat infections.Surgery, however, does not always address the sleep apnea and acontinuous positive airway pressure(CPAP) machine may be useful.Physical therapy and participation in physical education may improve motor skills.cite bookWearmouthJaniceSpecial educational needs, the basics2012RoutledgeMilton Park, Abingdon, Oxon978-1-136-57989-966http://books.google.com/books?idEvidence to support this in adults, however, is not very good.cite journalAndrioloRBEl Dib, RP; Ramos, L; Atallah, AN; da Silva, EMAerobic exercise training programmes for improving physical and psychosocial health in adults with Down syndromeThe Cochrane database of systematic reviewsMay 12, 20105CD0051762046473810.1002/14651858.CD005176.pub4RamosLAtallahA. N.Da SilvaE. M.

Efforts to preventrespiratory syncytial virus(RSV) infection withhuman monoclonal antibodiesshould be considered, especially in those with heart problems.In those who develop dementia there is no evidence formemantine,cite journalMohanMBennett, CCarpenter, PKMemantine for dementia in people with Down syndrome.The Cochrane database of systematic reviewsJan 21, 20091CD0076571916034310.1002/14651858.CD007657donepezil,cite journalMohanMCarpenter, PKBennett, CDonepezil for dementia in people with Down syndrome.The Cochrane database of systematic reviewsJan 21, 20091CD0071781916032810.1002/14651858.CD007178.pub2rivastigmine,cite journalMohanMBennett, CCarpenter, PKRivastigmine for dementia in people with Down syndrome.The Cochrane database of systematic reviewsJan 21, 20091CD0076581916034410.1002/14651858.CD007658orgalantamine.cite journalMohanMBennett, CCarpenter, PKGalantamine for dementia in people with Down syndrome.The Cochrane database of systematic reviewsJan 21, 20091CD0076561916034210.1002/14651858.CD007656

Plastic surgeryhas been suggested as a method of improving the appearance and thus the acceptance of people with Down's.cite journalRoizenNJComplementary and alternative therapies for Down syndrome.Mental retardation and developmental disabilities research reviews2005112149–551597731510.1002/mrdd.20063It has also been proposed as a way to improve speech.Evidence, however, does not support a meaningful difference in either of these outcomes.Plastic surgery on children with Down syndrome is uncommon,and continues to be controversial.The U.S.National Down Syndrome Societyviews the goal as one of mutual respect and acceptance, not appearance.cite webNational Down Syndrome SocietyPosition Statement on Cosmetic Surgery for Children with Down Syndromehttps://www.ndss.org/About-NDSS/Media-Kit/Position-Papers/Cosmetic-Surgery-for-Children-with-Down-Syndrome/http://web.archive.org/web/20060906164622/http://www.ndss.org/content.cfm?fuseaction2006-09-062006-06-02

Many alternative medical techniques are used in Down syndrome; however, they are poorly supported by evidence.These include: dietary changes,massage,animal therapy,chiropracticsandnaturopathy, among others.Some proposed treatments may also be harmful.
article.heading: Prognosis
article.paragraph: Between 5 and 15% of children with Down syndrome in Europe attend regular school.Some graduate from high school; however, most do not.cite bookSteinbockBonnieLife before birth the moral and legal status of embryos and fetuses2011Oxford University PressOxford978-0-19-971207-6222http://books.google.ca/books?id2ndOf those with intellectual disability in the United States who attended high school about 40% graduated.cite webNumber of 14- through 21-year-old students served under Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, Part B, who exited school, by exit reason, age, and type of disability: 2007-08 and 2008-09https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d11/tables/dt11_118.aspNational Center for Education Statistics7 February 2014Many learn to read and write and some are able to do paid work.In adulthood about 20% in the United States do paid work in some capacity.cite newsSzaboLizLife with Down syndrome is full of possibilitieshttp://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/01/life-down-syndrome-improving/2054953/7 February 2014USA TodayMay 9, 2013cite webDown's Syndrome: Employment Barriershttp://www.rehacare.com/cipp/md_rehacare/custom/pub/content,oid,15324/lang,2/ticket,g_u_e_s_t/mcat_id,7738/local_lang,2Rehab Care International7 February 2014In Europe, however, less than 1% have regular jobs.cite webEuropean Down Syndrome Association newshttp://www.down-syndrome.eu/files/profiles/edsa_sweden.pdfEuropean Down Syndrome Association7 February 20142006Many are able to live semi-independently,but they often require help with financial, medical, and legal matters.Those with mosaic Down syndrome usually have better outcomes.cite bookNelsonMaureen R.Pediatrics2011Demos MedicalNew York978-1-61705-004-688http://books.google.ca/books?id

Individuals with Down syndrome have a higher risk of early death than the general population.This is most often from heart problems or infections.Following improved medical care, particularly for heart andgastrointestinalproblems, the life expectancy has increased.This increase has been from 12 years in 1912,cite bookRichard UrbanoHealth Issues Among Persons With Down Syndromehttp://books.google.com/books?id9 September 2010Academic Press978-0-12-374477-7108to 25 years in the 1980s,to 50 to 60 years in the developed world in the 2000s.Currently between 4 and 12% die in the first year of life.The probability of long-term survival is partly determined by the presence of heart problems. In those with congenital heart problems 60% survive to 10 years and 50% survive to 30 years of age.In those without heart problems 85% survive to 10 years and 80% survive to 30 years of age.About 10% live to 70 years of age.

Y.AlvaradoMAndersonH. R.AndersonL. M.AndrewsK. G.AtkinsonCBaddourL. M.Barker-ColloSBartelsD. H.BellM. L.BenjaminE. J.BennettDBhallaKBikbovBBin AbdulhakABirbeckGBlythFBolligerIBoufousSBucelloCBurchM29More children are born with Down syndrome in countries where abortion is not allowed and in countries where pregnancy more commonly occurs at a later age.About 1.4 per 1000 live births in the United Statescite journalParkerSEMai, CT; Canfield, MA; Rickard, R; Wang, Y; Meyer, RE; Anderson, P; Mason, CA; Collins, JS; Kirby, RS; Correa, A; National Birth Defects Prevention, NetworkUpdated National Birth Prevalence estimates for selected birth defects in the United States, 2004–2006Birth defects research. Part A, Clinical and molecular teratologyDec 201088121008–162087890910.1002/bdra.20735and 1.1 per 1000 live births in Norway are affected.In the 1950s, in the United States, it occurred in 2 per 1000 live births with the decrease since then due to prenatal screening and abortions.cite bookMenkesJohn H.Child neurology2005Lippincott Williams & WilkinsPhiladelphia, PA978-0-7817-5104-9228http://books.google.ca/books?id7thSarnat, Harvey B.The number of pregnancies with Down syndrome is more than two times greater with many spontaneously aborting.cite bookRobert M.KliegmaNelson textbook of pediatrics.2011SaundersPhiladelphia1-4377-0755-6Chapter 76.219thDown Syndrome and Other Abnormalities of Chromosome NumberIt is the cause of 8% of allcongenital disorders.

Maternal age effectMaternal ageaffects the chances of having a pregnancy with Down syndrome.At age 20, the chance is one in 1441; at age 30, it is one in 959; at age 40, it is one in 84; and at age 50 it is one in 44.Although the probability increases with maternal age, 70% of children with Down syndrome are born to women 35 years of age and younger, because younger people have more children.ThePaternal age effectfather's older ageis also a risk factor in women older than 35, but not in women younger than 35, and may partly explain the increase in risk as women age.cite bookPaternal influences on human reproductive success2013Cambridge University Press978-1-107-02448-965http://books.google.ca/books?idDouglas T. Carrell
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: File:The Adoration of the Christ Child Follower of Jan Joest of Kalkar.jpgthumbleftupright=1.4It has been suggested that thisEarly Netherlandish paintingdepicts a person with Down syndrome as one of the angels.cite journalLevitasASReid, CSAn angel with Down syndrome in a sixteenth century Flemish Nativity painting.American journal of medical genetics. Part AFeb 1, 2003116A4399–4051252280010.1002/ajmg.a.10043English physicianJohn Langdon Downfirst characterized Down syndrome as a separate form of mental disability in 1862, and in a more widely published report in 1866.cite journalDown, JLH1866Observations on an ethnic classification of idiotsClinical Lecture Reports, London Hospital3259–62http://www.neonatology.org/classics/down.html2006-07-14cite bookJohn Langdon Down, 1828–1896Conor, WORoyal Society of Medicine Press1-85315-374-51998douard Sguindescribed it as separate fromcretinismin 1944.cite journalNeriGOpitz, JMDown syndrome: comments and reflections on the 50th anniversary of Lejeune's discovery.American journal of medical genetics. Part ADec 2009149A122647–541992174110.1002/ajmg.a.33138By the 20th century, Down syndrome had become the most recognizable form of mental disability.

In ancient times, many infants with disabilities were either killed or abandoned.A number of historical pieces of art are believed to portray Down syndrome, including pottery from AD 500 from South America and the 16th-century paintingThe Adoration of the Christ Child.

In the 20th century, many individuals with Down syndrome were institutionalized, few of the associated medical problems were treated, and most died in infancy or early adult life. With the rise of theeugenics movement, 33 of the then 48U.S. statesand several countries began programs of forced sterilization of individuals with Down syndrome and comparable degrees of disability.Action T4inNazi Germanymade public policy of a program of systematicInvoluntary euthanasiainvoluntary euthanization.cite bookDavid WrightDowns:The history of a disability: The history of a disabilityhttp://books.google.com/books?id25 August 201225 August 2011Oxford University Press978-0-19-956793-5104–108

With the discovery ofkaryotypetechniques in the 1950s, it became possible to identify abnormalities of chromosomal number or shape.In 1959,Jrme Lejeunereported the discovery that Down syndrome resulted from an extra chromosome.However, Lejeune's claim to the discovery has been disputed,cite bookDavid WrightDowns:The history of a disability: The history of a disabilityhttp://books.google.com/books?id25 August 201225 August 2011Oxford University Press978-0-19-956793-5145and in 2014, the Scientific Council of the French Federation of Human Genetics unanimously awarded its Grand Prize to his colleagueMarthe Gautierfor this discovery.cite newsTrisomie : une pionnière intimidéehttp://www.lemonde.fr/sciences/article/2014/02/03/trisomie-une-pionniere-intimidee_4359331_1650684.html25 March 2014Le MondeFeb 3, 2014As a result of this discovery, the condition became known as trisomy 21.cite bookDavid WrightDowns:The history of a disability: The history of a disabilityhttp://books.google.com/books?id25 August 201225 August 2011Oxford University Press978-0-19-956793-59–10Even before the discovery of its cause, the presence of the syndrome in all races, its association with older maternal age, and its rarity of recurrence had been noticed. Medical texts had assumed it was caused by a combination of inheritable factors that had not been identified. Other theories had focused on injuries sustained during birth.cite bookWarkany, JCongenital MalformationsChicagoYear Book Medical Publishers, Inc1971313–140-8151-9098-0

article.heading: Name
article.paragraph: Due to his perception that children with Down syndrome shared facial similarities with those ofMongoloidBlumenbach's Mongolian race, Down used the term 'mongoloid'.cite journalWardOCJohn Langdon Down: the man and the message.Down's syndrome, research and practice : the journal of the Sarah Duffen Centre / University of PortsmouthAug 19996119–2410890244While the term mongoloid (also mongolism,Mongolian idiocyMongolian imbecility or idiocy) continued to be used until the early 1970s, it is now considered unacceptable and is no longer in common use.cite journalHoward-JonesNorman1979On the diagnostic term "Down's disease"Medical History231102–04153994108240110.1017/s0025727300051048In 1961, 19 scientists suggested that "mongolism" had "misleading connotations" and had become "an embarrassing term".cite journalRodríguez-HernándezMLMontoya, EFifty years of evolution of the term Down's syndrome.LancetJul 30, 201137897894022180320610.1016/s0140-6736(11)61212-9TheWorld Health Organization(WHO) dropped the term in 1965 after a request by the Mongolian delegate.

In 1975, the United StatesNational Institutes of Health(NIH) convened a conference to standardize the naming and recommended eliminating the possessive form, Down's syndrome,cite journal1975Classification and nomenclature of morphological defects (Discussion)[[The Lancet]]51330579054697210.1016/S0140-6736(75)92847-0although both the possessive and nonpossessive forms are used by the general population.cite bookSmithKieronThe politics of Down syndrome2011Zero[New Alresford, Hampshire]978-1-84694-613-43http://books.google.ca/books?idThe term "trisomy 21" is also used frequently.cite bookWestmanJudith A.Medical genetics for the modern clinician.2005Lippincott Williams & WilkinsPhiladelphia, PA978-0-7817-5760-7136http://books.google.ca/books?id
article.heading: Ethics
article.paragraph: Some argue that not to offer screening for Down syndrome is unethical.cite journalChervenakFAMcCullough, LBEthical considerations in first-trimester Down syndrome risk assessment.Current opinion in obstetrics & gynecologyApr 2010222135–82012501410.1097/gco.0b013e3283374a9fAs it is a medically reasonable procedure, perinformed consent, people should at least be given information about it.It will then be the woman's choice, based on her personal beliefs, how much or how little screening she wishes.cite journalChervenakFAMcCullough, LBSharma, GDavis, JGross, SEnhancing patient autonomy with risk assessment and invasive diagnosis: an ethical solution to a clinical challenge.American journal of obstetrics and gynecologyJul 2008199119.e1–41835578310.1016/j.ajog.2008.02.021cite journalZindlerLEthical decision making in first trimester pregnancy screening.The Journal of perinatal & neonatal nursingApr–Jun 2005192122–31; quiz 132–31592396110.1097/00005237-200504000-00008When results from testing become available, it is also considered unethical not to give the results to the person in question.cite journalSharmaGMcCullough, LBChervenak, FAEthical considerations of early (first vs. second trimester) risk assessment disclosure for trisomy 21 and patient choice in screening versus diagnostic testing.American journal of medical genetics. Part C, Seminars in medical geneticsFeb 15, 2007145C199–1041729973610.1002/ajmg.c.30118

Some deem it reasonable for parents to select a child who would have the highest well-being.cite journalSavulescuJKahane, GThe moral obligation to create children with the best chance of the best life.BioethicsJun 2009235274–901907612410.1111/j.1467-8519.2008.00687.xOne criticism of this is it often values those with disabilities less.cite journalBennettRThe fallacy of the Principle of Procreative Beneficence.BioethicsJun 2009235265–731847705510.1111/j.1467-8519.2008.00655.xOthers argue that Down syndrome shouldn't be prevented or cured and that eliminating Down syndrome amounts to genocide.Cite webHalifax mom questions Down syndrome suppressionhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/halifax-mom-questions-down-syndrome-suppression-1.13234012015-09-26Cite webShould Down Syndrome Be Cured?http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/11/should-down-syndrome-be-cured/?_r2015-09-26LisaBelkinTheDisability rightsdisability rights movementdoes not have a position on screening,although some members consider testing and abortion discriminatory.cite journalParensEAsch, ADisability rights critique of prenatal genetic testing: reflections and recommendations.Mental retardation and developmental disabilities research reviews20039140–71258713710.1002/mrdd.10056Some in the United States who arepro-lifesupport abortion if the fetus is disabled, while others do not.cite journalGreenRMParental autonomy and the obligation not to harm one's child genetically.The Journal of law, medicine & ethics : a journal of the American Society of Law, Medicine & EthicsSpring 19972515–15, 21106647610.1111/j.1748-720x.1997.tb01389.xOf a group of 40 mothers in the United States who have had one child with Down syndrome, half agreed to screening in the next pregnancy.

WithinChristianity, someProtestantsdenominations see abortion as acceptable when a fetus has Down syndrome,whileOrthodox ChristiansandRoman Catholicsoften do not.cite bookEncyclopedia of religious controversies in the United States.2013ABC-CLIOSanta Barbara, Calif.978-1-59884-867-0278http://books.google.ca/books?idBill J Leonard, Jill Y. Crainshaw2ndSome of those against screening refer to it as a form of "eugenics".Disagreement exists withinIslamregarding the acceptability of abortion in those carrying a fetus with Down syndrome.cite journalAl-AlaiyanSAlfaleh, KMAborting a Malformed Fetus: A Debatable Issue in Saudi Arabia.Journal of clinical neonatologyJan 2012116–112402767410.4103/2249-4847.922313761984Some Islamic countries allow abortion, while others do not.Women may face stigmatization whichever decision they make.cite bookWoman-centered care in pregnancy and childbirth2010Radcliffe Pub.Oxford978-1-84619-161-9140http://books.google.ca/books?idSara Grace Shields, Lucy M. Candib
article.heading: Advocacy groups
article.paragraph: Advocacy groups for Down syndrome formed after theSecond World War.cite bookDowns: The history of a disability2011Oxford University Press978-0-19-161978-6147http://books.google.ca/books?idDavid WrightThese were organizations advocating for the inclusion of people with Down syndrome into the general school system and for a greater understanding of the condition among the general population,as well as groups providing support for families with children with Down syndrome.Organizations included theMencapRoyal Society for Handicapped Children and Adultsfounded in the UK in 1946 byJudy Fryd,cite webTimelinehttp://www.mencap.org.uk/about-us/our-history/timelineMENCAP2 February 2014Kobato Kai founded in Japan in 1964,the National Down Syndrome Congress founded in the United States in 1973 byKathryn McGeeand others,cite webNational Down Syndrome Organizations in the U.S. http://www.globaldownsyndrome.org/about-down-syndrome/resources/national-down-syndrome-organizations-2/Global Down Syndrome Foundation2 February 2014and theNational Down Syndrome Societyfounded in 1979 in the United States.

The firstWorld Down Syndrome Daywas held on 21 March 2006.cite webWorld Down Syndrome Dayhttp://www.ds-int.org/world-down-syndrome-dayDown Syndrome InternationalDown Syndrome International2 February 2014The day and month were chosen to correspond with 21 and trisomy, respectively.cite bookPrattGeraldineThe global and the intimate feminism in our time2012Columbia University PressNew York978-0-231-52084-3113http://books.google.ca/books?idRosner, VictoriaIt was recognized by theUnited Nations General Assemblyin 2011.
article.heading: Research
article.paragraph: See alsoDown syndrome researchEfforts are underway to determine how the extra chromosome 21 material causes Down syndrome, as currently this is unknown,and to develop treatments to improve intelligence in those with the syndrome.cite journalGoodmanMJBrixner, DINew therapies for treating Down syndrome require quality of life measurement.American journal of medical genetics. Part AApr 2013161A4639–412349523310.1002/ajmg.a.35705One hope is to usestem cells.cite journalBriggsJAMason, EAOvchinnikov, DAWells, CAWolvetang, EJConcise review: new paradigms for Down syndrome research using induced pluripotent stem cells: tackling complex human genetic disease.Stem cells translational medicineMar 201323175–842341337510.5966/sctm.2012-01173659762Other methods being studied include the use ofantioxidants,gamma secretase inhibition,adrenergic agonists, andmemantine.cite journalCostaACScott-McKean, JJProspects for improving brain function in individuals with Down syndromeCNS DrugsSep 2013279679–7022382104010.1007/s40263-013-0089-3Research is often carried out on ananimal model, the Ts65Dn mouse.cite journalCostaACOn the promise of pharmacotherapies targeted at cognitive and neurodegenerative components of Down syndromeDevelopmental neuroscience2011335414–2721893967325404010.1159/000330861
